status_message:
#SydneyStorm update:

- The Transport Management Centre says non-essential travel should be avoided across the road and transport network due to the adverse weather conditions throughout Sydney, Newcastle and the Central Coast.

- Bexley Road is now closed at Wolli Creek due to flooding - motorists are advised to avoid the area.

- The M4 eastbound on-ramp from Silverwater Road is also closed due to flooding.

- Galston Road is closed near Carters Road in Galston due to a serious car and truck accident.

- More than 250 traffic signals between Sydney and Newcastle are currently out of service. Many other roads are affected by flooding, fallen trees and wires.

- Sydney Trains is currently reporting delays on the T2 Airport Line, the T2 Inner West and South Line, the T4 Eastern Suburbs Illawarra Line, and major delays on the T3 Bankstown Line.

status_message: Last night's vigil for the victims of the Charlie Hebdo attack in Sydney's Martin Place (raw footage). #CharlieHebdo #JeSuisCharlie

The Charlie Hebdo Officiel attack is horrifying no matter what way you look at it, but it's almost bewildering when you consider the target. 

The attackers weren't fighting the French state. They weren't killing soldiers. They weren't even attacking a far-right group. Instead, they were targeting satirists and cartoonists. Why?

bit.ly/1BNqPc3

Comment: Environment minister Greg Hunt MP will have to acknowledge that greenhouse gases have declined thanks to the carbon price, writes Gareth Hutchens.

Carbon emissions declined across Australia by 1.4 per cent in the second year of the carbon tax, compared with a decline of 0.8 per cent in the first year.

Economists had predicted that that would happen. It takes a while for new markets to begin working properly.
link_name: Economists got it right on carbon tax

Andy Bernardos was working as a waiter at Kirribilli's Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron, when he saw the for-sale sign in the window of McKenzie's in 1979. "It was $84,000, walk in walk out â€” that's the freehold and the stock." Mr Bernardos didn't know a thing about hardware.

Mr Bernardos, who is 73, hopes for another decade or so of selling screws and nails. It makes enough, he says â€” just. "Banana sandwiches for lunch." His three sons have forged other careers so, one day, Mr Bernardos will have to shut up. "When I get old I will," he says.

status_message:
The latest on the #SydneySiege, which is now in its tenth hour. 

- Five hostages have emerged. Police cannot confirm how many hostages remain inside.
- The situation is now a 'negotiation' and police are pursing a peaceful end to it, however the crisis may continue into tomorrow.
- Police will not confirm what the hostage taker is asking for and have asked media not to publish any reports of his requests.
- Police say people should go about their business as usual, including going into the city this evening if they had plans to do so. An exclusion zone remains around Martin Place.
link_name: Lindt Chocolat Cafe hostage drama in Martin Place, Sydney

status_message: Three hostages escape from the Lindt cafe in Martin Place, Sydney, as the siege continues. Live coverage: http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/lindt-chocolat-cafe-hostage-drama-in-martin-place-sydney-20141215-1278cx.html #SydneySiege

On Friday, the State Government's new European Red Fox Pest Control Order officially came into force, allowing greater control of an invasive feral predator that spreads disease and causes carnage to both livestock and native wildlife.

status_message:
Here's the latest update on the Sydney storm:

- A lightning bolt appears to have struck the Sydney Tower Observation Deck, creating a shower of sparks and plunging the structure into darkness about 10pm.

- Sydney Airport has been closed due to the high winds

- The Bureau of Meteorology says flooding in the lower lying area of Tempe is imminent. The Tempe Bridge is expected to be flooded around 1am.

- Power outages are being reported at Bexley, Bankstown and Blakehurst. About 5500 homes are said to be affected.

- The NSW SES has so far rescued people from eight cars that have become caught on flooded roads in Sydney tonight. 

Follow our live blog for the latest updates: http://ow.ly/CIZjs 

(Photo by Jo Horan)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
UPDATE: Since 8pm, Sydney Airport has had 14.2mm of rain, Bankstown has had more than 32mm and Canterbury has had more than 17mm. 

According to the Bureau of Meteorology, winds are reaching speeds of 65km/h, and gusts of 95km/h at Sydney Airport. At Bellambi, winds have reached 87km/h with gusts of 102km/h at 7pm. Wattamolla has been slammed with strong winds of 135km/h just before 9pm, with gusts of 161km/h.

The NSW SES has so far rescued people from eight cars that have become caught on flooded roads in Sydney tonight. 

Thousands of homes in Sydney's south are experiencing power outages. Ausgrid says 5,500 homes are without power, including in Bexley, Bankstown and Blakehurst. Crews are currently working to restore power. 

Follow our live blog: http://ow.ly/CIM17
link_name: Timeline Photos

Julia Gillard has accused Kevin Rudd of sabotage and blackmail, but expressed deep and lingering anguish over her own role in toppling Kim Beazley.

In My Story, the memoir to be launched by Quentin Bryce on Friday, Ms Gillard vigorously defends her decision to turn on Mr Rudd in 2010, but confesses to misgivings about working with Mr Rudd to bring down Mr Beazley four years earlier.
link_name: Gillard accuses Rudd of sabotage and blackmail

status_message:
It was a terrorist plot marked by its brutality and simplicity, and the ease with which it could be rolled out at a moment's notice: kidnap innocent bystanders, whisk them back to a secret location and execute them by means of decapitation.

After the murderous spectacle of passenger jets ploughing into buildings on September 11, 2001, and the nightclub bombings in Bali that left hundreds dead, this week's alleged plot was decidedly low tech.

But it had all the ingredients that make for a successful terrorist act - to terrify, to prey on the deepest human instincts to create widespread fear. http://ow.ly/BHNag
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Police believe unbearable strain and hardship brewed within quiet grain farmer Geoff Hunt, following a car crash that left his wife Kim disabled.

This week it is believed he killed Kim, 41, and their three children before turning a gun on himself at the family's Riverina property near Wagga Wagga.

Detectives working on the case said there had been considerable pressure and tension following the crash, in which Kim Hunt twice flipped her car two kilometres from her Lockhart home in 2012.
link_name: Strains that grew inside Geoff Hunt ended in five deaths on a farm

status_message:
Sydney temperatures are warming up a bit, with the 17C already warmer than yesterday's 15.7C max. 
That low temperature was the coolest for Sydney this early in the season for 31 years, while Canberra's 9.1 degrees was also the lowest max since 1983, according to Rob Sharpe, a meteorologist at Weatherzone. Thredbo Top, which had its first decent snow falls of the season on Saturday, saw temperatures dip to minus-4 overnight.
Good news for those who don't like the chill is that Sydney's temps should warm up a bit, reaching 20-22 over most of the coming week.
There's also unlikely to  be another strong cold front coming through for another two weeks, Weatherzone's Mr Sharpe said.
link_name: Timeline Photos

It was notably undiplomatic language for Australia's Foreign Minister, Julie Bishop, to use in a public space.

"I'm lol'n so much right now at this," the Foreign Minister added to another person on the popular social network. She followed that post with more than a dozen tweets, littered with hahas and LOLs and ROFLs and LMFAOs.

The serial paedophile found guilty of murdering Queensland schoolboy Daniel Morcombe has been sentenced to life in prison, with a non-parole period of 20 years.

Bruce and Denise Morcombe and their sons, Dean and Bradley, declined to be in the courtroom when Justice Rosyln Atkinson handed down her sentence.

"In view of criminal histories and the enormity of the crime that you have committed it is appropriate in my view to set the parole eligibly date after you have served 20 years of your sentence," Justice Atkinson said.

status_message:
UPDATED - Follow our live blog for the latest on the fire at the Barangaroo development site: http://ow.ly/uuEPD 

- A fire has broken out in the basement of a building at Barangaroo. Firefighters are unable to access the fire due to excessive heat and humidity.

- Thick, black smoke is continuing to pour out of the construction site at the CBD's western foreshore.

- No injuries have been reported and surrounding buildings have been safely evacuated.

-The safety of a 50 metre crane is of great concern with fears it could topple. Firefighters are keeping a close eye on the crane's movements and are working to keep the base cool.

- Multiple roads through Sydney's CBD are already gridlocked and peak hour commuters attempting to travel into or out of the city by bus are being warned to expect delays.

- The Western Distributor has been closed in both directions with north-bound traffic diverted to the Anzac Bridge. The traffic is also affecting buses and bus commuters will be allowed to use their tickets on trains and ferries.

Comment: ''Whatever these people are fleeing, whatever circumstance makes them think they'd be better off chancing death on boats hardly worthy of that description, we must offer them something worse. That something is Papua New Guinea.''

We don't get to be outraged because this violence, with its brutal, deadly consequences, is inherent. We chose it, even if we've refused at every stage to acknowledge that. It is the very logic of our asylum seeker policy - which is built on the sole rationality of deterrence - to create horror, writes Waleed Aly.
link_name: The whole point of detention for asylum seekers is horror, whether it is acknowledged or not

status_message:
Comment: Whatever the spin or obfuscation, Immigration Minister Scott Morrison cannot avoid a glaring fact. Australia has condemned those seeking asylum to a country where it cannot - and has not - been able to guarantee them safety.

Once the fence had been breached, they were where Australia had purposefully placed them: in a poverty-stricken foreign country known for chronic law and order problems and a police force known for brutality, writes Tony Wright.
link_name: The bottom line is simple: Australia put these people at risk

status_message:
Eamonn Duff's personal account of what happens when you write a book accusing Schapelle Corby of being a drug smuggler:

Life has never been the same since. Two years ago, I stood before the national media and outlined evidence that showed the drugs had belonged to her father, Mick Corby. My publisher, Richard Walsh, stood beside me that day and said Allen & Unwin agreed. The book, Sins of the Father, reveals how Mick Corby regularly bought marijuana from a South Australian drug syndicate headed by convicted drug trafficker Malcolm McCauley. It discloses how and why McCauley visited Schapelle in jail two weeks before her verdict.

Read more: http://www.smh.com.au/national/dealing-with-threats-just-a-small-part-of-reporting-on-schapelle-corby-case-20140208-328lz.html#ixzz2smULLakQ

status_message:
Here's what's been happening overnight in Sochi at the Winter Olympics: 

Norway's Ole Einar Bjoerndalen tied a Winter Olympics record with his 12th medal by taking gold in the biathlon 10-kilometer sprint on Saturday, and an American half his age spun more than four times in the air to win in snowboarding.

Canadian sisters Justine and Chloe Dufour-Lapointe won gold and silver in women's moguls freestyle skiing, becoming the first siblings to finish 1-2 in an Olympic event since Phil and Steve Mahre of the United States in the 1984 men's slalom. American Hannah Kearney, the defending champion, took bronze in moguls.

Read more: http://www.smh.com.au/sport/winter-olympics/all-the-winners-on-day-two-at-sochi-20140209-329dl.html#ixzz2sm1bwiBO

status_message: Good morning from Sydney. Pleasant morning which will give way a bit to a windy afternoon. Winds should be 25-40 km/h over the city and 40-50km/h along the coast, the Bureau of Meteorology tells us. Downtown looking at 28C maximum, but go west and the mercury climbs higher, with Penrith expecting 38C. Not a great day in prospect for the state's fire fighters, with regions such as the far south coast and the southern slopes and the ACT expecting 'severe' fire risks. (Good luck to Victorians and those in SA too, with fire risks also very high in those two states.)

Despite video footage of the asylum seekers showing their burns, Mr Morrison said the claims were "unfounded, unsubstantiated, outrageous allegations against our navy and our customs and border protection service".

It wasn't quite as big as Jaws, but a group of Lake Macquarie fishermen were left wondering if they were going to need a bigger boat after landing a 320-kilogram monster tiger shark about 30 nautical miles off Swansea.

Ben, 25, told the Newcastle Herald that he battled with the shark for about two hours off the Shelf during the Lake Macquarie Game Fishing Club summer pointscore on Sunday, eventually getting it into his mate's boat.

But Ben is now facing an online backlash, with critics hitting out at him and his "trophy" photographs.

status_message:
Comment 

It's time to say goodbye to posties, writes Peter Martin.

Mail deliveries are falling at the rate of 4 to 5 per cent a year. Twelve years ago Australia Post delivered an average of 2.2 local letters or bills to each street address. It is now 1.7 and on track to fall to 1.3 by 2016, sliding further beyond that.

When the national broadband network is complete there will be no excuse whatsoever for daily mail deliveries. Australia's really remote locations are already limited to two deliveries per week. That should become the standard for the rest of us, as a precursor to eliminating local deliveries.

http://ow.ly/sAEFl
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
How far should Sydney residents have to walk to get to a stop on the city's new tram line?

The issue might not be the most pressing among the city's many transport needs, considering the overcrowded trains, inadequate roads and unreliable buses.

But the question of ''stop spacing'' on the new light rail line to the eastern suburbs - and how to resolve the tension between a tram running fast and one that stops where people want it to - is the latest subject of divisions between the state government and councils along the route.

http://ow.ly/sAzi3
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The author of Australia's largest study into alcohol-related nightlife crime has blasted Premier Barry O'Farrell for ''unbelievably stupid'' comments that 1am lockouts and 3am closing times would do little to prevent 9pm assaults such as the one from which Daniel Christie died.

Peter Miller's five-year study found lockouts and early closing times in Newcastle encouraged drinkers to go to venues earlier, instead of pre-loading at home and arriving in the city drunk.

Associate Professor Miller, from Deakin University, said it was ''very scary'' for a premier to be parroting the hotel industry rather than looking at evidence-based research. ''It's just a terrible argument. What sort of premier says it wouldn't have changed these two single incidents?'' he said.

http://ow.ly/sAjli
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Comment 

The old, industrial ''stand and deliver'' model of education is long gone. The idea that teachers are in charge and that they just download their solid wisdom into students' minds may still exist in the consciousness of Christopher Pyne and company, but they do not exist in the real world.

We don't get to tell students what to think any more. A great relief.

Yet at a time when you can practically track year 12 success by looking at the home postcodes of the students who sit the exam, why is it the curriculum that's under review?

http://bit.ly/1m3V8C3
link_name: Timeline Photos

The University of South Australia has distanced itself from a proposal for a series of male studies courses, some of which were to be taught by hardline anti-feminist advocates.

The university has approved one of four proposed graduate courses, a certificate in male health and health promotion, which will begin online next month.

But an original proposal by one of the university's academics outlined three further certificates, including a course called ''males and sexism'', which named lecturers who have been published on radical men's rights websites.

status_message:
The family of a British tourist who died while saving his sons who were caught in a rip on the NSW south coast say it is "heartbreakingly impossible" to imagine their life without him.

Andrew Priestley, 46, was swimming with his two sons Matthew, 12, and Daniel, 10, at an inlet leading to Burrill Beach on Friday when the boys began struggling in the water and screamed for help.

Mr Priestley, a businessman from Market Harborough in Leicestershire, kept his sons afloat and lifted them on to a surfboard before onlookers paddled them to shore. But by the time the rescuers returned for Mr Priestley, he was floating face down in the water, just north of the entrance to Burrill Lake.

"All she is, is a host for a foetus."

A 33-year-old Texas woman declared brain dead is being kept on life support in hospital against her instructions because she is pregnant. 

Texas is one of more than two dozen US states that prohibit, with varying degrees of strictness, medical officials from cutting off life support to a pregnant patient. Her parents say she is being treated as little more than a ''host for a foetus''.
link_name: 'A host for a foetus': Brain dead pregnant woman kept on life support

The bride schools, known as ReichsbrÃ¤Â¨uteschules, initially only accepted women engaged to members of the SS. (They were barred from enrolment if they had Jewish or gypsy heritage, physical disability or mental illness.)

status_message: From the Archive: Australian racing motorist, Norman "Wizard" Smith, in his race car the "Enterprise". This photo, taken circa 1931, has been scanned from one of Fairfax's glass plate negatives and was recently uncovered through the digitisation project being undertaken in conjunction with the National Library of Australia. The fabulously futurist styled chassis of the Enterprise was designed and built by Sydney engineer Donald Harkness, and was powered by a 1700 horsepower aircraft engine. Wizard Smith set a world speed record of 164.084 miles (264.06 km) per hour in January 1932, but failed in his bid to better the prestigious flying-mile and five mile records.

Western Sydney Liberal candidate Fiona Scott has said she believes asylum seekers are contributing to outer-suburban traffic jams: http://ow.ly/ouRpl. 

''[Asylum seekers are] a hot topic here because our traffic is overcrowded,'' she said. ''Go sit on the M4, people see 50,000 people come in by boat - that's more than twice the population of [western Sydney suburb] Glenmore Park,'' she told the ABC's Four Corners program.

Refugee Action Coalition spokesman Ian Rintoul described Ms Scott's comments as ''shockingly ignorant'' and said there were only a few thousand refugees in the area.

(Photo by Alex Ellinghausen)

status_message:
Veteran British broadcaster David Frost had a genius for access, and he interviewed nearly everyone who was anyone, including six American Presidents (among them, of course, Richard Nixon), eight British Prime Ministers, several members of the Royal family and a galaxy of celebrities. He had a phenomenal memory and an instinctive understanding of the value of flattery; most of his interviewees considered themselves personal friends.

Obituary: David Frost, 1939-2013. http://ow.ly/osVP6 

(Photo from our archives. David Frost, left, talks with Australian prime minister Gough Whitlam in Sydney in 1973. Photo by George Lipman.)

status_message:
''When Britain joined the Common Market, the establishment was defeatist, declinist and obsessed with the idea that we were being left out of the world's most powerful economic club. In those days - when olive oil and garlic had barely appeared on the dining tables of Britain - it was assumed that in order to be ''internationalist'' it was enough to be European. It is perfectly obvious, in 2013, that that is no longer enough.

''We need to raise our eyes beyond Europe, forging and intensifying links with countries that are going to be growing in the decades ahead; countries that offer immense opportunities for British goods, people, services and capital. And you could not do better than by starting with Australia.''

It is time for Britain and Australia to set up a bilateral free labour mobility zone, writes London mayor Boris Johnson: http://ow.ly/oikpQ.

(Photo by AFP)

status_message:
Tampering of speed limiter devices is continuing at alarming rates within the trucking industry despite an unprecedented 18-month crackdown on rogue operators after a triple fatality crash. http://ow.ly/ofWye 

The rate of tampering was as high as one in four trucks stopped during an April operation on the M5. It included one truck in Botany with a speed limiter reconfigured to allow speeds of up to 193km/h.

Highway Patrol Commander Superintendent Stuart Smith launched a tirade on the industry, asking: "What will it take for some of these companies to abide by the law? Another triple-fatal crash? Another family's life destroyed?''
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
It's been 50 years since iconic civil rights leader Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech, and though progress has been made, the struggle continues. http://ow.ly/og4Ix 

The 50th anniversary is an appropriate time to reflect on how far America has come, and how far it still has to go, to be the society King imagined, writes Dr Michael L. Ondaatje.

"King was more than a dreamer who solved the problems of the past. His vision challenges Americans to confront the problems of the present, and to be ever vigilant in pursuing justice and equality in the future."

The first viral video of the 2013 election campaign could be described as a Diaz in the headlights. 

The Liberal Party's Jaymes Diaz marked the start of his pitch for Sydney's most marginal electorate with an interview so excruciating that Opposition Leader Tony Abbott called to commiserate.

Mr Diaz' six-minute interview with Channel 10 - which is now making news in the US - reached its painful peak when he told reporter John Hill the Coalition had a six-point plan to stem the flow of asylum seekers, but failed to outline the five points other than 'turn back the boats'.

A pregnant Sydney woman is seeking an apology from Jetstar after she was escorted from a domestic flight to the Gold Coast for failing to provide a medical certificate clearing her to fly.

Mother-of-one Fiona Stuart was almost 30 weeks pregnant at the time, and had consulted her doctor about the trip a day before departure as part of a routine check-up. 

With her doctor's approval, Ms Stuart checked-in for her 8.55am flight on Friday, July 26. But a Jetstar flight attendant approached her once she and her two-year-old son had taken their seats on the plane and asked her to produce a medical certificate to show she was safe to fly.

Read more: http://ow.ly/nyRNr

status_message:
Transport Minister Gladys Berejiklian has defended a Sydney Trains plan to schedule trackwork during next weekend's City2Surf.

Buses will replace trains on parts of the Bankstown, Inner West and South lines next weekend, when about 85,000 registered participants are expected to travel into central Sydney for the world's biggest fun run on Sunday.

The August 11 event, which is wholly owned and organised by Fairfax Media, comes two months after Roads Minister Duncan Gay admitted to being "blindsided" by the huge crowds that jammed trains and brought traffic to a halt during the final weekend of Vivid Sydney.

Read more, plus trackwork schedules: http://ow.ly/nyJEB

status_message: From the Photo Archive: this dramatic image was captured on this day,  29th July 1991. It shows a close up of anti-logging protesters in the Chaelundi State Forest, northern New South Wales. The Sydney Morning Herald reported at the time that "opponents of logging operations in the Chaelundi State Forest dug in for a long vigil against Forestry Commission plans to cut access roads and fell timber in the 560 hectares of old-growth area in the State's north-east." Five and half years later, in January 1997, the Chaelundi National Park was created covering 19,174 hectares.  Photo by Rick Stevens.

status_message:
"I came here from Afghanistan in November 1999, when I was 18 years old. We had 77 people on a 30-foot fishing boat. We ran out of water and food. Any proper food we had we gave to an Iraqi family, because they had young children to feed. So we just ate dried biscuits, with boiled rice every second or third day."

Now, Riz Wakil - an ethnic Hazara who spent nine months in Curtin Detention Centre - owns his own business in Sydney's Fairfield, a printing and design company that turns over $300,000 annually and employs five people. http://ow.ly/nbap2 

(Photo by Jenny Evans)

status_message:
The inner city's top cop has called for a ban on new licensed premises in George Street as figures reveal authorities are approving almost every application for central Sydney.

Commander of the central metropolitan region Mark Murdoch said it was his ''firm belief'' that no more pubs, bars or clubs should be allowed in the area in a bid to curb drunken violence.

The assistant police commissioner said the lifting last year of a three-year freeze on licences might have contributed to a rash of violent incidents in George Street. These include two king hits in two months on telecommunications worker Simon Cramp, 26, and finance worker Matthew Blackmore, 33, both of whom were lucky to escape alive. 

''We've got enough licensed premises. We don't need any more. I don't care how big or small, we just don't need any more,'' Mr Murdoch said.

''You don't have to walk too far anywhere in Sydney now, whether it's George Street, Oxford Street or Kings Cross where you can't get a drink. If anyone argues we need more [licensed venues] they're kidding themselves.''

http://ow.ly/n9eTJ
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
It's hard to call Android anything other than a resounding success. Well, except for one small thing: most Android phones are lousy. 

As part of a New Year's resolution, I promised to trade in my beloved iPhone 5 for an Android phone sometime in 2013. I reasoned that, as a tech writer, I should spend more time with the world's most popular operating system. 

Over the last few months, though, I've been testing two of the most expensive, most advanced Android phones on the market, the Samsung Galaxy S4 and the HTC One. 

Altogether I experienced the best and worst of Android - and I saw, up close, Android's basic problem.

http://ow.ly/n9btW

status_message:
He invented something you probably use every day, yet haven't given a lot of thought to.

Douglas Engelbart, the inventor of the computer mouse, has died at the age of 88: http://ow.ly/mEdGB. 

A few facts:
- Engelbart invented the mouse in 1963 - long before the influx of personal computers
- He once said he 'didn't know why' he and his team called it a mouse, but has also said it was because it resembled a rodent with a long tail. He later wondered why no-one had come up with a more 'appropriately dignified' name
- Engelbart earned no royalties from his invention, but did win a $US500,000 prize for inventors in 1997
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Chris Johnston reports from Nhulunbuy, East Arnhem Land for this sad event: 

Alan James, OAM, was a close friend of Mr Yunupingu, the Yothu Yindi band leader and indigenous educator who died almost four weeks ago of kidney disease, aged only 56. James was the band's manager and a friend for 28 years. He recalled on Saturday how he met the man who he says brought black and white Australia together like no other.

A state memorial for Mr Yunupingu will be held on sacred Aboriginal land on Sunday at Gulkula, a one-time space tracking station near Nhulunbuy (Gove) in East Arnhem Land.

James was touring Aboriginal performance groups around Northern Territory schools when that first introduction came. At Yirrkala Community School, where Mr Yunupingu would later become the nation's first Aboriginal principal, he sought out James when he heard he was coming.

"He said 'hop in.' So I got in his short wheel base Toyota and we drove out to where he was living and sat on the beach and he played me five songs on the guitar and that was that. We shook hands and nearly 30 years later here we are."

Yothu Yindi â€“ meaning child and mother â€“ were top ten worldwide in 1991 with the song Treaty, co-written by Paul Kelly. They performed at the United Nations in New York in 1992 for the International Year of Indigenous Peoples. In 2000 they closed the Sydney Olympics. The following year Treaty was named in the top 30 Australian songs of all time.

Mr Yunupingu, the singer and guitarist, was the first Aboriginal from Arnhem Land to get a university degree. He was named Australian of the Year in 1993, was inducted into the ARIA Hall of Fame and helped set up the Yothu Yindi foundation, a cultural and education centre for his Yolngu people.

Read more: http://ow.ly/muYl2
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Good time to brush up the Bahasa perhaps:

Former prime minister John Howard has re-emerged to kick start Tony Abbott's election campaign, taking aim at Kevin Rudd over border protection and accusing him of severely damaging Australia's relationship with Indonesia.

At a "US-style presidential rally" in Melbourne on Saturday, Mr Howard delivered a scathing assessment of the resurrected prime minister, accusing him of being the architect of Labor's asylum seeker policy which he dubbed "the single biggest policy failure of this government."

The comments come a day after Mr Rudd stepped up his attack on the Coalition's "stop the boats" policy over asylum seekers, warning the idea could spark a diplomatic conflict with Indonesia. (Mr Rudd stuck by those comments on Saturday.)

Mr Howard hit back on Saturday, accusing the prime minister of being a "policy chameleon" on border protection and jeopardising the relationship he had spent years building with our regional neighbour.

Read more: http://ow.ly/muU7U
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Here's one item generating a bit of heat today:

Bert and Ernie. Gay? We always suspected, but we never knew.

In the wake of the US Supreme Court's landmark ruling to overturn the Defence of Marriage Act, New Yorker magazine has decided to answer the question.

That ruling grants same-sex couples the "equal liberty" guaranteed by the US constitution's Fifth Amendment.

In response, the magazine has put Bert and Ernie â€” the iconic residents (and roomates) of the long-running children's TV series Sesame Street â€” on the cover of next week's issue.

The cover image â€” titled Moment of Joy â€” depicts them sitting on a couch, Bert's arm wrapped around Ernie and Ernie's head nestled against Bert's shoulder.

They are seen watching the Supreme Court decision on a black and white TV.

Read more here: 
http://ow.ly/muQxx
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
And here's the big political news of the day (so far):

Kevin Rudd's return to the Labor leadership has dramatically reversed a poll slide in the party's heartland seats, suggesting the severe election losses feared under Julia Gillard's leadership can be avoided.

A new poll reviving Labor hopes came as Mr Rudd stepped up his attack on Opposition Leader Tony Abbott's "stop the boats" policy, warning it risked sparking conflict with Indonesia.

Mr Rudd also warned that a Coalition government could plunge Australia into recession if it adopted the harsh spending cuts he believes the opposition is planning.

He also signalled significant policy changes, including the possible dumping of the carbon tax in favour of a lower floating carbon price and a two-week extension of the negotiation period of the education funding package, and softened his language on a big Australia in favour of a sustainable Australia.

Read more: http://www.smh.com.au/national/rudd-poll-bounce-boosts-labor-20130628-2p366.html?rand=1372465761878

status_message:
Good morning from a soggy Sydney.
Reckon this item sums it up:

Don't put away those gumboots just yet.

More rain is expected in Sydney today and on Sunday, pushing rainfall totals for the month well past double the long-run average of 131 millimetres.

For the near-term outlook, today should see the heaviest falls before easing slightly on Sunday and even further by Monday.

"It's not really until late Monday or perhaps Tuesday that we will see some blue sky" in Sydney, said Drew Casper-Richardson, a meteorologist at Weatherzone.

As of Saturday morning, the city's rain gauges had collected about 265 millimetres of rain for June, including more than 40 millimetres in the 24 hours to 9am. That's the most for any month in six years.

Read more: 

http://www.smh.com.au/environment/weather/what-a-front-more-wet-weather-on-its-way-for-sydney-20130628-2p2nq.html?rand=1372461411913

status_message:
This was one of the top stories on smh.com.au today, and it's well worth reading.

''We cannot have a humane life. There are many things we cannot have. We can afford meat only once or twice in a month, we cannot buy medicine if we are sick.''

Forhad Mia and his wife Raifa are factory workers in Bangladesh, making shirts that Australians buy in Kmart for $15. Together, they earn about $130 a month.

The supply chain that ends with customers at a Western department store and begins with Forhad at his sewing machine is complex and clandestine. But all along its length there is pressure, of those above pushing down on those below: customers expect bargains in a competitive retail world; retailers demand ever-lower prices from suppliers; suppliers connive for fractions of a cent off each garment made, on pain of pulling their orders from factory owners; and factory owners hold wages at worldwide lows and force unpaid overtime on their powerless, expendable workers.

Ever downwards the pressure is forced - until it reaches Forhad at his machine. http://ow.ly/mjwsy.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Liberal MP Don Randall has called the Gillard government's new laws cracking down on the skilled foreign worker visa scheme "the most racist piece of legislation" he has ever seen http://ow.ly/maBYK. 

The bill includes new rules to ensure Australians get priority for jobs and would force employers wishing to hire foreign workers under the 457 visa program to prove they had tried and failed to recruit suitable local employees first.

Mr Randall, who was first elected as a WA Liberal MP in 1996, attacked the government for putting forward the bill in its "dying days", describing it as "xenophobic" and "jingoistic" in its attitude to foreign workers.

(Photo: Don Randall pictured in 2007 at his family's bakery with Vietnamese baker Hao Van Pham, who Mr Randall employed on a 457 visa. Photo by Erin Jonasson)

Protests by a quarter of a million people have swept Brazil, as demonstrators express their anger over the amount of money being invested in the World Cup, and an increase in bus fares: http://ow.ly/mavvd. 

In scenes rarely seen in Brazil since the fall of the dictatorship in 1985, crowds took to the streets, carrying placards reading: ''World Cup for Who?'' and ''We don't need the World Cup''.

And in Australia, peaceful demonstrations took place in Melbourne's Federation Square, Sydney's Hyde Park and Brisbane yesterday, attracting Australian-born Brazilians, residents and students.

status_message:
Should the rules be changed in the middle of the Origin series? Here's what the refs chief says:

As criticism was aimed at the NRL over the new stricter guidelines on fighting, referees boss Daniel Anderson defended the mid-season crackdown, maintaining rugby league's image needed to be protected.

Referees have been told to use the sin bin for punching an opponent from this round on in the wake of NSW skipper Paul Gallen's fight with Queensland's Nate Myles in State of Origin I.

Some, including pundit and former champion halfback Peter Sterling, have applauded the move. But others have accused the league of a knee-jerk reaction, and an unnecessary one. Others have questioned whether the referees would need to bin multiple players in the event of an all-in brawl.

Read more:http://ow.ly/m4znq

status_message:
The federal government is imposing an interim national ban on 19 synthetic drugs after Sydney teenager Henry Kwan took an LSD-like drug and fell to his death.

The ban will prohibit the sale and supply of the drugs for 120 days, giving state and territories time to update their legislation and outlaw synthetic drugs.

"Synthetic drugs are dangerous substances that can kill and should not be available for sale," minister assisting for deregulation David Bradbury said.

Read more:http://ow.ly/m4wia

status_message:
Are fights on the sporting field something to be applauded?

Simon Cramp was supposed to be at game one of the State of Origin series on Wednesday night. He had a ticket to join friends and 80,000 other screaming passionate NSW Blues fans for the first of the epic annual rugby league battles.

If he had been there, Cramp too may have risen to his feet in euphoric celebration of a mid-field altercation, ecstatic as Blues captain Paul Gallen levelled a series of punches to the head of opposing player Nate Myles.

But he was not there - the 26-year-old was in a hospital bed, sporting a zipper scar down his skull, extensive bruising to his head and an unimaginable feeling of relief that he was even alive.

It was a barrage of punches just like those Gallen was so lauded for landing on the stage of a sports field that nearly killed Simon Cramp.

http://ow.ly/lPym7
link_name: Timeline Photos

Hayne is expected to be out for between two and four weeks after suffering a grade one tear ''at the muscle attachment to the tendon'' during Parramatta's 38-24 loss to the Roosters on Friday night.

The news is a blow to the Blues, who are looking to wrap up the series when they travel to Suncorp Stadium for game II on June 26.

http://ow.ly/lPxw8

Good morning. These are our lead stories today:

Synthetic drug sellers have offered to foot a $200 million bill to test the legality of their products in a bid to keep selling them to Australians, following the death of north shore student Henry Kwan.
 http://ow.ly/lPcpz 

Young university researcher Peter Woof didn't know it yet but as he walked towards the Wentworth building at Sydney University early on a Monday morning, he was heading for a physical confrontation with Tony Abbott that would land both men in court.
It was September 25, 1978. http://ow.ly/lPcCy 

The cost of mental illness to Australia's collective wellbeing has reached $190 billion a year - equivalent to about 12 per cent of the economy's annual output. (with interactive) http://ow.ly/lPcIo 

And we are headed for a mostly sunny day with a top of 19C. 
Enjoy your Herald today.

status_message:
Peter Traynor held his son James in his arms for half an hour one morning in January, believing he was dead. The 20-year-old was unconscious and blue in the face, his eyes had disappeared into the back of his head, his body was sweaty and battered after being found on the bathroom floor of the family's Gunnedah home, he was choking on his vomit and thrashing around in a psychotic state. James was rushed to Tamworth Hospital and saved by a team of doctors but what came next left the Traynor family dumbfounded.

The substance that had almost killed their son was something they had never heard of: a $20 packet of ''synthetic cannabis'' from a local video shop. It is a common reaction among the growing number of families who have been devastated by the effects of ''legal highs'' on their loved ones: http://ow.ly/lDCYR.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
In a surprise admission, an 86-year-old former Khmer Rouge leader has expressed remorse and accepted responsibility for the deaths of an estimated 1.7 million people during the organisation's murderous rule in the 1970s: http://ow.ly/lzdSz.

"I am responsible for what happened during the time of Democratic Kampuchea," said Nuon Chea, the Khmer Rouge's chief ideologue and "brother number two", referring to Cambodia's name during the Khmer Rouge's "killing fields" era from 1975 to 1979.

No other Khmer Rouge leader has ever admitted responsibility or apologised for one of the darkest chapters of the 20th century.

status_message: A thick fog settled over Sydney this morning, caused by moisture left in the air after rain last night, causing flight delays, ferry cancellations and heavy traffic.
link_name: Heavy fog blankets Sydney

status_message:
Good morning to our Sydney readers, who have woken to a very thick fog over the city.

It was caused by heavy rains overnight which left a lot of moisture around, according to the weather bureau. It is expected to lift around 9am.

The fog has delayed eight incoming international flights and caused delays on the F3 - drive carefully everyone.

Our photographer Kate Geraghty took this shot at Iron Cove a short time ago. More details via our AM news blog, Morning Expres http://ow.ly/lrpiz.

status_message:
The most powerful meteor strike on the moon ever observed has just been announced by NASA.

A March 17 strike on the moon caused an explosion equal to five tons of TNT and could have seen with the naked eye, said Bill Cooke, head of NASA's Meteoroid Environment Office.

"It exploded in a flash many times as bright as anything we've seen before," said Dr Cooke. "Anyone looking at the moon at the moment of impact could have seen the explosion, no telescope required. For about one second the impact site was glowing like a fourth-magnitude star."

http://ow.ly/l9Kvc
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
When it comes to the division of domestic labour and paid work, it seems many Australian families are still stuck in a time warp where dad brings home the bacon, and mum cooks it and does the dishes.

Research from the Australian Institute of Family Studies has found women spend almost twice as much time on housework and childcare than men, even when they increase their time in paid employment. Meanwhile, men do more paid work: http://ow.ly/l7hjU. 

Are you surprised by these findings? How does the division of paid work, housework and childcare (if you have kids) work in your home?
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Today we have a comment piece by Vic Alhadeff, the chief executive of the NSW Jewish Board of Deputies and a member of the NSW Human Rights Award judging panel.

He takes on the use of the word 'Nazi' in everyday ways, such as 'Grammar Nazi'. And, of course, there's that Seinfeld episode.

''I'm a Seinfeld aficionado. I've watched each episode a ridiculous number of times, yet still find the humour brilliant,'' he writes. ''But 'The Soup Nazi' trivialises the meaning of what a Nazi is, and in doing so degrades the language associated with those who devised, planned and perpetrated the most grotesque genocide in history.'' 

''This is neither about censorship nor about curtailing the right to humour. It is a concern about how we use language and the impact of that.'' Read his piece in full: http://ow.ly/l7d2b.

status_message:
Actress Angelina Jolie has revealed that she recently underwent a preventative double mastectomy http://ow.ly/l05EI. 

Writing for The New York Times, Jolie, whose mother died of ovarian cancer, said she made the decision after finding out she carried a 'faulty' gene that increased her risk of developing breast cancer and ovarian cancer. 

"My doctors estimated that I had an 87 per cent risk of breast cancer and a 50 per cent risk of ovarian cancer, although the risk is different in the case of each woman," she wrote.

Jolie wrote that she revealed her decision publicly because she hopes other women can benefit from hearing about her experience.

Mothers feed their child fresh fruit and vegetables, send them to private schools, enrol them in lots of extra-curricular activities and limit their television watching to the ABC.

Newborn babies are being traded on a lucrative black market in Indonesia that could involve hundreds of children a year, some going illegally to parents offshore.

Pregnant women have been propositioned to give up their babies at pre-natal health checks and new mothers approached in the maternity ward, according to a court case due to start on Tuesday that exposes the trade.

The country's child protection commission says thousands of children have been bought and sold over the past 15 years. http://ow.ly/kVuAQ

status_message:
Scientists have identified a list of words that have remained pretty much unchanged for the past 15,000 years. 

The traditional view is that words can't survive for more than 8000 to 9000 years - but but new research suggests a few words survive twice as long. 

The most conserved word is "thou," the singular form of "you". "I," "not," "what," "mother" and "man" are also on the list. So are the verbs "to hear," "to flow" and "to spit," and the nouns "bark," "ashes" and "worm". Together, they hint at what has been important to people during the past 15 millenniums.

The odd little speech posted below would probably have been understood by a band of hunter-gatherers in the Caucasus 15,000 years ago. Read more on this fascinating story: http://ow.ly/kObcx.

Some are handling their situation better than others but all are generally tender in the company of strangers when the topic of children arises; hormonal, sensitive and often depressed, in a world of pain that does not cope well with smug assumptions.

status_message:
Crime stats show NSW is a much safer place than it used to be despite rises in certain pockets around Sydney. http://ow.ly/k8xva 

Across the state, robberies have plummeted and the murder rate is half of what it was 20 years ago. According to Dr Don Weatherburn, director of the Bureau of Crime Statistics and Research, the biggest problem the state faces is recurring spikes of non-fatal shootings in Sydney's southwest but even they are not increasing in a statistically significant way.

Despite the fear mongering of radio shock jocks, law and order is a low priority for NSW says Dr Weatherburn. "It's rather ironic that just when it ceased to be an issue in state politics, it became an issue of federal and state relations." 

Do you agree? To what extent does crime impact on your daily life?
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The green side of fracking: US emissions of carbon dioxide have fallen back to 1995 levels. The primary reason is "fracking", ie hydraulic fracturing to access shale gas deposits, writes Harvard professor Jeffrey Frankel. http://ow.ly/k8ru8

Natural gas emits only half as much CO2 as coal, and occupies a rapidly increasing share of electricity generation â€“ up 37 per cent since 2007, while coal's share has plummeted by 25 per cent. Indeed, natural gas has drawn close to coal as the number one source of US power. Natural gas use also improves local air quality and has economic and political benefits by way of job creation and reduced dependency on Middle East oil.

Yet environmentalists are overwhelmingly opposed to fracking for reasons of safety, an aversion to reliance on fossil fuels and the "precautionary principle" of avoiding unknown risks. None of these arguments is persuasive, writes Professor Frankel.

Do you agree that the benefits of fracking outweigh the risks? Or is there more to the issue than this article addresses?

(Photo: Bloomberg)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
OPINION: Australian society will remain class-bound without the Gonski reforms, writes Tim Colebatch.

"It is an issue that defines what kind of country we want to be. Do we want Australia to be a broadly egalitarian country, where all children have access to a good education, and the opportunity it gives them to make a good start in life? If so, we should be honest, and admit that is not what we have now.

Or would we prefer to be a class-based society, where good opportunities are available to those with the money to buy them, and the rest get a basic service? That is the principle that drives federal funding for schools under the Howard government model, which looks after students in private and Catholic schools, and leaves students in public schools to the financially impoverished states."

Do you agree? If so, are the Gonski reforms the right way to go about redressing inequitable education outcomes?

status_message:
Settling the NBN debate: How much internet speed do we really need? The answer depends on whether we're talking about current needs are the likely demand in the foreseeable future. http://ow.ly/jUZux 

While the Coalition's 25Mbps minimum broadband plan may be adequate for current usage, bandwidth requirements are rapidly multiplying. Many households now have multiple large screens connected to the web as well as several portable devices such as smartphones and tablets. 

Futurist Mark Pesce, honorary associate in digital cultures at the University of Sydney, said in 10 years time the average household would have "north of 100 devices" connected.

Fibre-to-the-home, which is Labor's proposal, is technically infinitely upgradeable.

Is your internet access adequate to your current needs? Is it even reliable? Which plan would you rather see implemented?

(Photo: Peter Mathew)

status_message:
North Korea closes border to tourists. Read more: http://ow.ly/jUOov 

A key border crossing between North Korea and China has been closed to tourist groups, a Chinese official says, as nuclear tensions mounted, but business travel was allowed to continue. 

On Tuesday, Pyongyang advised foreigners to consider leaving South Korea, warning that the Korean peninsula was headed for "thermo-nuclear" war.

Last week, North Korean authorities also warned embassies in Pyongyang to consider evacuating as it would be unable to guarantee diplomats' safety in the event of conflict, but the statement was largely dismissed as empty rhetoric. 

(Photo: AFP)

status_message:
OPINION: Our obsession with NAPLAN and other standardised tests fosters corruption, writes Save Our Schools national convenor Trevor Cobbold. http://ow.ly/jUKZ8 

Test-based accountability provides too many incentives for officials, principals and teachers to rig results. This was highlighted by the indictment last month of the former US national Superintendent of the Year Beverley Hall on racketeering charges. Hall was charged, along with 34 other school administrators, principals and teachers, for cheating and manipulating test scores. 

In 2009, Hall was lauded for turning the Atlanta school system ''into a model of urban school reform''. The improvements proved to be phoney. The indictment alleges Hall and the others cheated on state tests, hid the cheating, and retaliated against whistleblowers.

Read more: http://ow.ly/jULva 

What do you think? Has NAPLAN delivered better results for your children?

(Photo: stock image)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Call for weight limits in school rugby following the death of Jake Kedzlie - grandson of rugby league legend Tommy Raudonikis. The 15-year-old's tragic death has put the spotlight back on the risk of serious head injuries in contact sports.

The president of NSW Schools Rugby Union, Colin Murray, said over the past 12 months there had been more consideration given to the idea of weight categories, particularly for players under 16, to allay fears about the increasing size of some young football players and the physical risks associated with collisions on the field.

''The players these days are more powerful, generally speaking, and the physique of the younger generation has changed,'' said Mr Murray, who has been involved in school rugby for about 40 years. ''It's just frightening in a way, the physical development of that generation coming through now, and you just wonder where it's going to stop.'' Read more: http://ow.ly/jScaE

Do you agree with proposals to introduce weight restrictions to school rugby?

Ebert had been a film critic for US newspaper Chicago Sun-Times since 1967. He had announced on his blog on Wednesday that he was undergoing radiation treatment after a recurrence of cancer.

status_message:
When it comes to cancer, saying someone 'lost their battle' isn't right, says Michael O'Reilly, whose sister Kathy died of ovarian cancer three years ago at the age of 49. 

''Why is death by cancer so often framed in this way?'' he writes.

''I've never heard of a pedestrian having 'lost their battle with a 10-tonne truck'. No octogenarian is said to have 'lost their battle with Father Time'.''

''I would like to see no more talk of 'losing'. We should rather remember that every day of life lived with cancer is a victory.'' 

Read his full piece: http://ow.ly/jJea8.

From the Archive: A ferry strike on Sydney Harbour was causing problems for commuters 100 years ago, 19 years before the opening of the Harbour Bridge. With the ferries on strike dozens of privately owned boats had swung into action and "the boatmen created a perfect babel in their desire to secure patronage", the Sydney Mail reported. There were dangers with so many small boats recrossing the harbour with their passengers while larger vessels moved up and down the harbour, but the traffic was in the circumstances admirably organised, according to the Sydney Mail, March 26 1913. More 1913 ferry strike photos here: http://tinyurl.com/d4qukag
For more from the archives read today's "In the Herald: April 4, 1859" here: http://www.smh.com.au/comment/in-the-herald-april-4-1859-20130403-2h6zv.html

status_message:
From the Archive: 30 years ago today, April 3 1983, the crowd at Mount Panorama's annual motorcycle races turned into a riot. The Herald reported "180 were hurt, 77 arrested after a six-hour riot" as "a mob of 3000 pelted police with petrol bombs, bricks and rocks at the Mount Panorama circuit." 22 year-old Herald photographer Gary McLean was quoted as saying "it was really wild, I was trying to do a job. But it was impossible not to be scared. I have never seen anything like it". While taking photographs "Mclean was showered with rocks and debris, struck in the middle of his back with a half brick and accidentally struck by a police baton", the Herald reported. See the story here http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-YxWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uOYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4988%2C1368166
For more from the archives read today's In the Herald: April 3, 1939 - http://www.smh.com.au/comment/1939-20130402-2h4sr.html
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
HECKLER: Telstra moved me and I didn't even have to pack. For reasons known only to itself, Telstra decided to drop the street number from my address, leaving only the unit number and a lot of irritation. 

At first, I just wondered where my bills had gone although the money was still coming out of my bank account. 

Then I met my postman on the street. He's a conscientious chap and had noticed that Telstra bills with my (somewhat uncommon) name were suddenly being addressed to a house a long way down the road. So he kindly sent them back to Telstra with a post office note that the address was wrong. 

Did Telstra think to, oh, I don't know, telephone me, to ask what was going on? Of course not, it just kept sending bills to the wrong address. So the postman told me when he saw me, and I called Telstra. That's when things really went downhill. Read more: http://ow.ly/jGNzm 

Do you have a utilities war story?

(Photo: Louie Douvis)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
How to crash a university website: urge female students to hurry up and marry the nearest classmate because they'll never have it so good dating-wise again. 

Susan Patton, a Princeton graduate and mother of two sons at Princeton crashed the Daily Princetonian website and caused a media furor in the US over her "Advice for the young women of Princeton: the daughters I never had". In her article, Patton counselled Princeton's female students to: "Forget about having it all, or not having it all, leaning in or leaning out - here's what you really need to know that nobody is telling you ... Find a husband on campus before you graduate."

Other gems from her op-ed included:

"For most of you, the cornerstone of your future and happiness will be inextricably linked to the man you marry, and you will never again have this concentration of men who are worthy of you.

"I am the mother of two sons who are both Princetonians. My older son had the good judgment and great fortune to marry a classmate of his, but he could have married anyone. My younger son is a junior and the universe of women he can marry is limitless. Men regularly marry women who are younger, less intelligent, less educated. It's amazing how forgiving men can be about a woman's lack of erudition, if she is exceptionally pretty. Smart women can't (shouldn't) marry men who aren't at least their intellectual equal. As Princeton women, we have almost priced ourselves out of the market. Simply put, there is a very limited population of men who are as smart or smarter than we are. And I say again â€” you will never again be surrounded by this concentration of men who are worthy of you."

The reaction from media commentators ranged from bemused to outraged. Read more: http://ow.ly/jGCYk 

What do you think: Offensive? Embarrassing? Or right on the money?
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Men headed for extinction? The poorly designed Y chromosome that determines maleness is degrading rapidly and will eventually disappear, says evolutionary geneticist. "You would think that sex is so important it wouldn't change a lot. But it changes all over the place and the Y chromosome sort of self-destructs," said Professor Jenny Graves. Y is always in the male and active mostly in the testes - making sperm. Read more: http://ow.ly/jGviS 

(Photo: James Davies)

status_message:
Big stink over fortnightly rubbish collection. Changes are ahead for the way we deal with household rubbish, starting with a move to fortnightly garbage pick-up. The most likely scenario is to have householders separate their food scraps, including dairy, meat and seafood, into a green organics bin, leaving their general waste bin filled with non-perishable items. "So the trend is to collect the garbage every fortnight and to collect the green and food organics every week", says Dr Ron Wainberg, president of the Waste Management Association of Australia. "In Victoria they're building composting facilities, there's a couple going in right now," he says. "NSW has just announced with the NSW waste levy review, there's some $400 million available for infrastructure development."

Do you support the composting of food waste if it's collected weekly? Is every two weeks frequent enough for general waste collection?

North Korea has been caught doctoring a photograph to double the number of hovercraft in a military exercise as part of its increasingly aggressive propaganda campaign: http://ow.ly/jubTd. 

The picture showed vessels with the same give-away shine on the front, moving through the water at an identical angle and throwing up spray that had been clumsily altered. 

North Korea's propaganda campaign is a response to UN sanctions punishing it for a nuclear test in mid-February and further antagonised by routine US-South Korean military exercises in the weeks that followed.

status_message:
The most dangerous travel destinations: More than 900 Aussies died overseas last year, with Thailand and Greece proving most fatal to tourists. 

Deaths in Thailand were largely due to illness or accident, while most deaths in Greece were from what the Department of Foreign Affairs calls ''natural causes'', pointing to a much older group travelling there. 

These statistics underline a key finding of a new Lowy Institute report highlighting the increasing burden travellers are putting on consular staff abroad. Overseas travel by Australians has doubled in the past decade leading to many more older - and younger, inexperienced - tourists coming into strife abroad.

The report slams a growing sense of "entitlement" among travellers who expect the Australian government to not only come to the rescue but, in the case of one couple who was evacuated from Cairo on a government chartered rescue flight, provide frequent flyer points as well. Read more: http://ow.ly/jrEno

What's your view? How far does the government's duty of care extend? How much consular support can Australians reasonably expect overseas?

(Infographic: Francisca Sallato. Source: DFAT)
link_name: Timeline Photos

Bookmaker Tom Waterhouse will be called to attend a specially convened parliamentary hearing into the spread of gambling into live sporting broadcasts: http://ow.ly/jrwAk. 

The 30-year-old Waterhouse has a multimillion-dollar deal with Channel Nine to exclusively spruik odds during football coverage but questions are being asked in Canberra as to whether he is sidestepping a new code of conduct designed to delineate the roles of commentator and bookmaker. After paying $15 million for the privilege, Waterhouse has been embedded with the Nine commentary team for NRL broadcasts, updating the changing odds but also giving his opinion on play.

status_message:
Are university degrees outdated? Most school leavers take the next step and go to university to obtain a degree. But with changing workplaces and the increasing speed of technology - to what degree do you need a degree? 

Of course if your life long dream is to be a scientist or a vet or a lawyer, higher education is not just necessary it's imperative to ensure you learn the knowledge required to execute these types of positions. But for many other industries where "hard skills" are required to get the job done is university always the right way to go? Do extra letters after your name really fetch extra dollars? Read more: http://ow.ly/jpHYm

status_message:
Tony Abbott may be PM before the "wall punch" defamation case is heard. A woman who accused Abbott of punching a wall on either side of her head while they were students at Sydney University, will not see her case heard until next year, well after the federal election.

Barbara Ramjan's suit has been deferred after Justice William Nicholas ordered the matter be heard by a 12-person jury, instead of the traditional four-person jury for civil trials, as the case could "excite prejudice and antagonism".

The case relates to comments by Liberal Party powerbroker Michael Kroger referring to Ramjan as "a nutter" and "a nobody." Read more: http://ow.ly/jetqE 

(Photo: Alex Ellinghausen)

status_message:
"Hero" students rescue driver from sinking car. A group of TAFE students dived into a lake at Sydney Olympic Park to save a woman from drowning when she lost control of her car and rolled down a hill into the lake. The landscaping students were returning by bus from an outing to the Royal Easter Show when they saw the car veer off Edwin Flack Drive. The students yelled at the driver to stop the bus before two of them dived into the lake and forced a car window open to free the trapped woman. The woman's husband hailed the young men as "heroes" saying, "they deserve bravery awards. They're awesome fellas." Read more: http://ow.ly/jeppP

(Photo: Channel 10)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Racism and the public transport test: Australians claim they're not racist. This study might suggest otherwise, writes Ross Gittins. Have you ever hopped on the bus only to find that your ticket didn't work in the machine? Did the driver kick you off the bus because you couldn't pay the fare? Or did he feel sorry for you and let you ride for free? The answer to that question will probably be very different depending on your race - and what you were wearing on the day. University of Queensland researchers have found that bus drivers are far less sympathetic to black or Indian passengers - unless they're wearing a suit or appear to be members of the military. Read more: http://ow.ly/jedKp 

What's your experience of racism in Australia?

(Photo: Andrew Quilty)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
PLEASE SHARE:
"Absolute disgrace" - Truck driver dumps two tonnes of asbestos outside of two inner city childcare centres. Security footage shows the truck, which drove through the area once before returning to dump the waste, had a piece of cloth over the numberplate, in an apparent bid to avoid detection. The city is now calling on any members of the public that recognise the white Daihatsu Delta, which was fitted with a non-standard bar that had been welded across the top of the tip tray. It also had a large crack near the driver's door when the tray is down and visible scratches on the tray and door on the driver's side. Anyone with information on the truck is asked to phone 02 9265 9333 or email council@cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au Read more: http://ow.ly/jcbQA

More than 20% of Norwegians tuned in to watch a 12-hour extravaganza about firewood. Then came the complaints.

'We received about 60 text messages from people complaining about the stacking in the program,' said Lars Mytting (pictured) whose best-selling book Solid Wood: All About Chopping, Drying and Stacking Wood â€” and the Soul of Wood-Burning inspired the broadcast. 'Fifty per cent complained that the bark was facing up, and the rest complained that the bark was facing down.'

He explained, 'One thing that really divides Norway is bark.'

As many as a thousand people this morning took part in the world's first nude ocean swim, the Sydney Skinny, in Sydney's Middle Harbour.

"There was an 89-year-old bloke, someone flew in from overseas, there were four paraplegics, a double amputee, there were fat people, thin people, young and old," said organiser Nigel Marsh. "It was just joyous. I am floating on cloud nine. It is probably one of the nicest days of my life."

status_message:
Free speech? In an opinion piece today, Richard Ackland writes we need to be careful what we defend to the death.

Referring to the recent cases in Sydney and Melbourne in which people subjected their fellow bus passengers to racist rants, he asks: If they instead delivered their thoughts to Jeremy Fernandez and the French woman in a peaceful and orderly way, as opposed to an intimidatory fashion, would it be all right? 

''All this flag waving about free speech in Australia is nice but a bit weird. We've never been a free speechy sort of country. As the media knows, we've been an expensive speech country. Take free speech too much to the bosom and you end up like the US of A, where the First Amendment says it's OK to sell videos of small animals being crushed to death, or to strike down laws that restrict massively rich individuals and corporations buying elections.''

Read the piece in full: http://ow.ly/hJzao and tell us what you think. Should the right to free speech be an absolute, or are there circumstances in which it should be restricted by law?

(Illustration by Simon Letch)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
How much time do you spend in the city at night?

The City of Sydney has released a strategy to revive the city at night over the next two decades, which would halve antisocial behaviour through measures such as creative outdoor lighting, cleaner streets and new CCTV cameras (and these pop-up urinals, pictured). Night bus services would double, and the council would encourage late-night busking and establish Australia's first 24-hour library. 

Just 6% of people in the city late at night are aged 40 or over - by 2030, the council hopes that figure will be 40 per cent.

Read more about the plan here http://ow.ly/hJlAl and tell us what you think. What would make you more likely to head out in the city at night?
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A security guard is being used to control wedding guests at historic Lindesay House at Darling Point after complaints from well-heeled neighbours including the media tycoon Kerry Stokes.

Lindesay, a heritage-listed property with manicured grounds and harbour views, is a prized wedding location. But after residents' complaints last year, wedding receptions must finish one hour earlier, at 9pm, with security on duty to encourage guests to leave promptly: http://ow.ly/hJghy.

It comes as residents of the exclusive harbourside suburb, including Mr Stokes and the retired car dealer Laurie Sutton, take legal action against Woollahra council over weddings at another location near their homes, McKell Park.

Do you think that's fair? Should residents have the right to put limits on events at public spaces that they say are disruptive? 

(Photo by Marco Del Grande)

A Telstra trial will see the internet speeds of BigPond ADSL customers who choose to share content via peer-to-peer networks deliberately slowed down during peak periods.

''While it is true that a lot of content downloaded over peer-to-peer networks is pirated material including music, movies and software; there is a lot of content that isn't,'' writes James Manning.

''Leaving the piracy issue aside, what gives internet service providers the right to selectively filter content and manipulate speeds based on that?'' 

Read the piece in full: http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/digital-life-news/dear-telstra-leave-my-interwebs-alone-20130213-2ech0.html and tell us what you think.(Photo by Glenn Hunt)

status_message:
A Chinese entrepreneur has come up with a solution as north China is once again choked in toxic smog - selling fresh air in soft drink cans, similar to bottled drinking water: http://ow.ly/hd6cp. 

Chen Guangbiao, whose wealth is valued at $740 million, told Fairfax Media he wanted to make a point that China's air was turning so bad that the idea of bottled fresh air is no longer fanciful.

"If we don't start caring for the environment then after 20 or 30 years our children and grandchildren might be wearing gas masks and carry oxygen tanks," he said.

The concentration of airborne PM 2.5 particulates â€” the smallest and most deadly â€” went off the chart in the early hours of this morning for the second time this month, according to pollution gauge at the American Embassy in Beijing.

(Photo by Yuan Jianmin)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Do you think the joke made by Tim Mathieson about prostate cancer and small female Asian doctors was in bad taste?

The Prime Minister's partner, Tim Mathieson, made a ''bad taste'' joke about Asian women and prostate cancer during a speech at The Lodge last night.

Ahead of the Prime Minister's XI cricket match today, Mr Mathieson addressed members of the West Indian cricket team about the importance of regular prostate examinations.

''We can get a blood test for it, but the digital examination is the only true way to get a correct reading on your prostate, so make sure you go and do that, and perhaps look for a small female Asian doctor is probably the best way,'' he said.

Prostate Cancer Foundation of Australia chief executive officer Anthony Lowe told ABC Radio that the joke was ''a bit unfortunate'', adding that it was harmful to the prostate cancer cause.

''We prefer that there's not too much humour around prostate cancer as it's such a serious subject,'' Dr Lowe said.

What do you think? Was the joke in bad taste? Is it wrong to try to bring attention to health causes using humour? Or should we lighten up?
link_name: Timeline Photos

A Chinese military officer has raised the spectre of nuclear weapons and warned Australia not to side with the United States 'tiger' and Japanese 'wolf' as a territorial dispute in the East China Sea continues to escalate: http://ow.ly/h2qw5. 

Senior Colonel Liu Mingfu directly warned Australia not to follow the US or Japan into any military conflict with China. He said Australia should play the role of a ''kind-hearted lamb'' and China would discourage it from being led astray.

Colonel Liu asked that his message be conveyed directly to the Prime Minister, Julia Gillard, as she prepares to deliver a major speech on national security today.

status_message:
Internet companies such as Facebook, Apple and Google provide free services but make billions of dollars each year by selling users' information to other companies, including custom advertisers.

And a new report by the Centre For Internet Safety says Australians are among the world's heaviest internet users but also the most exposed to being tracked online by companies after personal information: http://ow.ly/h0rct. 

The report calls for greater powers for the Office of the Information Commissioner to seize digital evidence, self-start investigations and penalise companies for privacy breaches. It also says Australians should be able to ask for a copy of data recorded about them that is being used for personalised advertising.

How aware are you of the information that companies are able to collect about you online? Are you worry about it? Do you take any precautions to ensure your privacy? Here are a few tips if you want to get started.
link_name: Timeline Photos

''Look, I don't have a mortgage on opinions, never have. But I have an opinion â€¦ always have and always will. It may not be an opinion you agree with, but that is OK. It is a democracy and I am happy to hear yours.''

status_message:
Comment: Sick of 'kiddie consumerism', mum Hattie Garlick has pledged to raise her son cost-free for a year.

''Clothes: a child's only requirement is to be warm and dry. We would use only swaps from friends or bundles from Freecycle, the website that matches people who have things they don't want with people who can use them. Toys: ditto. Food: out with the kiddy rice cakes, little cheeses and special squashes. He would just eat his share of the three meals a day that we cook for ourselves. Cloth nappies (given away via "swap or sell" pages on Facebook); kitchen haircuts; activities concocted at home instead of at soft-play centres. We could go a whole year without engaging in any kiddy consumerism, barring essential items such as medicines. Johnny wouldn't even notice.''

Read her piece here http://ow.ly/gQyrg then have your say - what do you think of the idea? Do we spend too much on our kids? Could they do - and perhaps be happier - with a lot less?

It might not be evident yet to shoppers, but amid the frenzy of clearance sales at Australia's venerable department stores, David Jones and Myer, prices on a wide range of goods are starting to come down. Permanently.

It is called ''price harmonisation'', a quaint euphemism for what is effectively a wrestle between the department stores and global brands suppliers to close the price gap between local retailers and their online rivals: http://ow.ly/gIztX. 

Do you think department stores cutting their prices will make you more inclined to shop there rather than online?

Photo: This spectacular gust front associated with cyclone Narelle was captured about 25 nautical miles north-west of Onslow in Western Australia on Wednesday. The red tinge results from dust picked up from the Pilbara. Photo by Brett Martin.

status_message:
Australia's most needlessly wasteful spending took place under the John Howard-led Coalition government rather than under the Whitlam, Rudd or Gillard Labor governments, an international study has found: http://ow.ly/gI7za.

The International Monetary Fund examined 200 years of government financial records across 55 leading economies. It identifies only two periods of Australian "fiscal profligacy" in recent years, both during John Howard's term in office - in 2003 at the start of the mining boom and during his final years in office between 2005 and 2007.

Do you find this news surprising?

Prime Minister Julia Gillard has announced a Royal Commission to investigate decades of child abuse in churches, schools and foster homes.

Ms Gillard said the commission would address "institutional responses to child abuse" - the instances of abuse as well as the manner in which they have been dealt - by a range of institutions.

http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/pm-announces-abuse-inquiry-20121112-29862.html
link_name: PM announces abuse inquiry

status_message:
Former prime minister Kevin Rudd has backed calls for a royal commission on child sexual abuse within the Catholic Church if state inquiries require bolstering, while Oppositon leader Tony Abbott says the Coalition is prepared to support whatever action the government takes.

Prime Minister Julia Gillard is considering calls for a federal inquiry but declined today to respond to the growing clamour for action as cabinet minister Penny Wong said any inquiry should be "full, frank and fearless".

Mr Rudd said a nationwide royal commission must be considered regardless of current state inquiries in NSW, Queensland and Victoria. Mr Abbott said any commission should inquire beyond the Catholic Church.
link_name: Rudd backs calls for church abuse commission

The average Australian wedding now costs $48,296. So is it not surprising that a growing number of couples are now choosing elopement, or something like it?

Sydney couple Lorraine Murphy and Wade Tink (pictured) recently got married on a doorstep in Bondi where they had met three years earlier, followed by a party with around 80 friends and family who thought they were there to celebrate the couple's joint 30th birthdays. At the party, they announced they had just married 'and the whole ceiling just lifted', says Lorraine http://ow.ly/fcAyl.

Does this sort of wedding - low-key and inexpensive - appeal to you? Or do you think it's one of those occasions in life where a big celebration is the only way to go?
