status_message:
The re-election of Barack Obama in the US and the handover of power to Xi Jinping in China have the potential to create a new paradigm in the world order.

A special forum tonight, broadcast on www.smh.com.au from 6pm, will feature Liberal MP Malcolm Turnbull, former prime minister Kevin Rudd, SMH political and international editor Peter Hartcher and Professor Geoff Garrett, Dean of the University of Sydney Business School.

The forum will consider how China will change under Xi Jinping and what Obama's re-election means for the US. It will ask what these changes in the two superpowers mean for their economies, social structures and relationship with each other and Australia. It will pose the question: are we on track to defeat the weight of historical precedent and avoid war between a rising great power and the reigning one?

The forum will consider Australia in this context, and ask whether we need to change our approach to accommodate this changing dynamic.

We invite you to ask a question - simply leave it as a comment below. The best will be selected for discussion by the panel.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Urgent: A public appeal from NSW Police, who have asked that this message be broadcast.

The NSW Police Force is seeking urgent public assistance to help locate a four-week-old boy who was taken from The Royal Hospital for Women at Randwick, in Sydney's east, late this morning.

At 11.40am today (Monday 5 November 2012), 26-year-old Justin Groves walked from the hospital on Barker Street, Randwick, with his infant son in his arms. Police don't believe Mr Groves has access to a vehicle. It's thought he might have left the area on foot or public transport. Police have concerns for the welfare of the baby boy due to his tender age. Mr Groves is not believed to have immediate access to a pram or other necessary baby supplies. He is described as being of Caucasian appearance, 170cm tall with a slim build, short crew cut hairstyle, and wearing a white T-shirt with blue print and light blue jeans. He has distinctive tattoos of skulls on his left arm and "Ally" tattooed on his neck. Police are asking the public to be on alert and immediately report any sightings of this man.

Members of the public are urged to ring Triple Zero (000) to provide information about this incident.

Opinion: The ALP fears most a Coalition switch to Malcolm Turnbull, the closest thing there is in politics to a sure thing. Labor is also wary of Scott Morrison, who harbours ambition and has a reputation for ruthlessness. Julie Bishop would also want to be considered if there was a move.

However, the word inside the Coalition is if Tony Abbott is hit by the proverbial bus, Joe Hockey would get the nod, writes Phillip Coorey: http://ow.ly/f0Wud.

Do you think Mr Hockey would make a good leader of the Opposition...or Prime Minister? And do think he would be a better leader than Mr Abbott?

Confessions of a troll: Jaime Cochran is a 20-something professional living in Chicago. She works all day on a computer, but her real labour, the one she loves, is hated around the world. Cochran is a self-identified troll. She trawls the internet day and night, looking for "victims" â€” emotional strangers Cochran deems ripe and right for a ripping.

It sounds cruel, but Cochran describes herself as a performance artist - "more cerebral than abrasive". Read the story here: http://ow.ly/euQrY.

status_message:
Last night's season two premiere of Homeland attracted 630,000 viewers, compared with about 1 million during the first season. That huge audience drop raises serious questions about the challenges facing traditional TV. The brutal reality is this: content that has screened in other parts of the world is increasingly subject to online piracy and other bypassing platforms such as iTunes, DVD and websites that allow internet browsers to get around 'geo-blocks' on content: http://ow.ly/etcfQ. 

Are you one of the patient viewers who waits for their favourite show to return to free-to-air TV in Australia, or do you find 'creative' ways to watch them as soon as they've aired overseas?

A fantastic photo from the front page of The Sydney Morning Herald print edition today.

It captures workers carrying out maintenance 80 metres above the road on the Anzac Bridge as part of a two-year, $61 million overhaul that will make life safer for Roads and Maritime Services staff responsible for the bridge's upkeep. Lifts will be installed to spare crews from dizzying climbs to maintain flags and antennas on pylons, while dampers at the base of each cable will reduce vibration.

status_message: Congratulations to @'CharlieCartmer', our 15,000th fan! And thank you to all of our fans who follow, and contribute to, this page. Have a great weekend everyone. Cheers, SMH Team.

On  the 10th anniversary of the Bali bombing, this documentary tells a story often ignored: the extraordinary Balinese response to the terrorist attack. Australian filmmaker John Darling's observations provide an insight into traditional and modern Balinese methods of grieving and healing. Among those who tell their own stories in the film are Haji Bambang, one of the heroes of the night. Many people died in his arms as he worked tirelessly to save victims or respectfully cover the dead. "There are moments here when you feel you have been punched in the chest. And you will cry," said Sydney Morning Herald's Bernard Zuel in his review. Watch it now on smh.tv: http://ow.ly/epYOg.

Opinion: Male anger is everywhere. Suddenly we're seeing it; misogyny is big. But it's not new, writes Elizabeth Farrelly.

''Male anger isn't always misogynistic, even when directed at women. (Misogyny isn't hating women, but hating them as women. Hating women as lefties, say, is not misogyny. It's just hate.) But male anger has always been a major life force. From Alan Jones to animalised footballers, from forced marriages to Taliban shootings, public male-on-female anger abounds.''

''Julia Gillard confronted a stark choice yesterday - the political defence of her parliamentary numbers, or the defence of the principle of respect for women. She chose to defend her numbers. She chose power over principle. It was the wrong choice. It was an unprincipled decision and turned out not to be pragmatic either. The Prime Minister gained nothing and lost a great deal,'' he writes: http://ow.ly/elAFb.

status_message:
Prime Minister Julia Gillard has lashed out at Opposition Leader Tony Abbott's record on sexism as the Coalition made a failed attempt to have Peter Slipper removed as Speaker by parliamentary vote. 
Ms Gillard said Mr Abbott should apologise to Parliament for the vile and sexist conduct of members of his own political party rather than using today's Slipper motion as a political battering ram.  She said she was personally offended when, as health minister, he said abortion was the "easy way out" and when he raised her unmarried status and when he stood beside the "Ditch the Witch" placards at anti-carbon tax rallies.
"I will not be lectured about sexism and misogyny by this man [Mr Abbott], not now, not ever," she told the house.
 "The Leader of the Opposition says that people who hold sexist views are not appropriate for high office. Well I hope the Leader of the Opposition has got a piece of paper and he is writing out his resignation." Full story: http://ow.ly/ek66b. 

Photo by Andrew Meares.

Kyle Sandilands has breached decency standards, the media authority has found, following a two-month investigation into comments he made on-air last year. It found the comments he made were deeply derogatory and offensive.

status_message: From the Archive: On this day, 25th March 1955, and in the category of "the more things change", the Herald carried this report of a touring Australian cricket team being undone by spin. Australia went on to win the 1955 series against the West Indies 3-0, but were having more problems against spin in the following year's Ashes defeat, a series famous for England off-spinner Jim Laker taking 19 wickets in a match.
link_name: Historic Herald front pages

status_message:
Timelines in the Herald 20th March 1918: Hats for Winter, from the Herald's "A Page for Women". Elsewhere that day a
Businesses for sale. Â£1000 would buy readers a "very long lease" on Sydney Harbour "pleasure resort". The price included a pavilion, dancing hall, boarding house, refreshment rooms, merry go-round, picnic grounds, swinging boats, "beautiful beaches" and furniture and effects. Otherwise, a "Music Shop and Circulating Library", suitable for a "lady or invalid", was on sale for Â£65 on Oxford Street.
Read more of today's timelines here: http://www.smh.com.au/comment/in-the-herald---march-20-1918-20130320-2gf6a.html

status_message: ''We will not rest satisfied until we get fair treatment''.  So a member of the Women's Vigilance Committee told the Herald 100 years ago today.  When our librarians were going through the archives for our retrospectives this week, they found this gem - published  on March 1, 1913. The women of the day were none too pleased when a female doctor was sacked. How far have we come in that 100 years?
link_name: Historic Herald front pages
